pageData.text: Students will collect drinking water samples and test them for factors that government laboratories and scientists use to monitor the health of municipal and well water sources.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: In most developed countries, people take it for granted that their drinking water is safe and nontoxic. Sadly, this is not always the case. Flint, Michigan experienced a water crisis in 2014 that exposed thousands of residents to unsafe levels of lead in their drinking water. It started when the city switched their drinking water from a regularly monitored source to the Flint River in an attempt to save money. However, the river water was improperly treated, and the correct levels of anti-corrosive chemicals were not added. Flint also had lead pipes in many areas, so when the poorly treated water flowed through them, lead leached from the pipes into the water supply. Lead is a neurotoxin that interferes with neuron signaling and cannot easily be dispelled from the body, so the risk from exposure is cumulative. Children are especially susceptible to the effects of lead in their developing nervous systems, in some cases leading to developmental delays and learning difficulties which can impact them over their lifetime. At very high levels, exposure can lead to seizures and death. When the issue was discovered, the community relied on bottled and filtered water until the water source could be switched back, but not before 6,000-12,000 children were exposed to harmful levels of lead. Since the incident in Flint, many communities across the US have made plans to remove lead pipes, but efforts are costly and slow going, leading to the possibility that another drinking water disaster could happen elsewhere.

pageData.desc: Water dripping from a tap into a glass.
pageData.altText: Water dripping from a tap into a glass.

pageData.text: Water is the compound most essential to life on Earth. Water covers approximately 75% of the earth’s surface, but only 2.5% of this is fresh water; further, an even smaller fraction of the fresh water is accessible for use and consumption. We depend on a clean water supply for drinking, cleaning, sanitation, recreation, and manufacturing. With such a small amount of the total volume of water available for consumption, it is important that the water that reaches households is clean and safe for drinking. Public health officials and scientists have developed tests that can be used to monitor the quality of natural waters and to locate sources (and potential sources) of water pollution.

The <button class='glossary-text'>Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)</button> has over 80 legally enforceable standards for drinking water contaminants. They are subdivided into the following categories: microorganisms, disinfectants, disinfection byproducts, inorganic chemicals, organic chemicals, and radionuclides.

Contaminants are typically measured in parts per million (ppm). This would mean that for each molecule of contaminant, there would be one million molecules of water. This number may seem insignificant, but the human body is sensitive to even very small changes in the concentration of chemicals. For some chemicals, the EPA limit can be as low as fractions of a ppm (<button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>).

The National Primary Drinking Water Regulations (NPDWR) are legally enforceable primary standards and treatment techniques that apply to public water systems. Primary standards and treatment techniques protect public health by limiting the levels of contaminants in drinking water.

pageData.title: Table 1. Example of EPA drinking water standards

Sources of Contaminant in Drinking Water

tableData.text: Reproductive difficulties; increased risk of cancer
Leaching from linings of water storage tanks and distribution lines
Water additive used to control microbes

Runoff from fertilizer use; leaking from septic tanks, sewage; erosion of natural deposits

tableData.text: Not a health threat in itself; it is used to indicate whether other potentially harmful bacteria may be present 5
Coliforms are naturally present in the environment; as well as feces; fecal coliforms and E. coli only come from human and animal fecal waste.
tableData.hoverText: Coliforms are naturally present in the environment; as well as feces; fecal coliforms and E. coli only come from human and animal fecal waste.

pageData.text: *MGLG (Maximum Contaminant Level Goal)-The level of a contaminant in drinking water below which there is no known or expected risk to health. MCLGs allow for a margin of safety and are non-enforceable public health goals.

**MCL (Maximum Contaminant Level)-The highest level of a contaminant that is allowed in drinking water. MCLs are set as close to MCLGs as feasible using the best available treatment technology and taking cost into consideration. MCLs are enforceable standards.

***MRDL (Maximum Residual Disinfectant Level) - The highest level of a disinfectant allowed in drinking water. There is convincing evidence that addition of a disinfectant is necessary for control of microbial contaminants.

****TT7 Action Level-Lead and copper are regulated by a treatment technique that requires systems to control the corrosiveness of their water. If more than 10% of tap water samples exceed the action level, water systems must take additional steps. For copper, the action level is 1.3 mg/L, and for lead is 0.015 mg/L.
Table modified from data provided by the EPA. https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water/national-primary-drinking-water-regulations#one

pageData.subTitle: Free and Total Chlorine
pageData.text: Levels of microorganisms, disinfectants, and disinfection byproducts are closely related. Municipal water supplies are typically disinfected with chlorine for the removal of pathogens. As part of this activity, the amount of free chlorine (disinfectant) and total chlorine (disinfectant/disinfection byproducts) are tested. Typically, excess chlorine can cause eye or nose irritation or stomach discomfort but does not have serious associated health concerns. The EPA limits for free chlorine is 4 ppm and total chlorine is 250 ppm.

pageData.subTitle: Nitrogen and Phosphorous
pageData.text: Most fertilizers contain nitrogen and phosphorus as water-soluble nitrates (NO3–) and phosphates (PO43–). Rain washes these water-soluble compounds from cultivated land into surface waters, leading to ecosystem enrichment, commonly referred to as . These nutrients then promote the rapid growth of plants and algae. Fertilizer runoff from lawns and farms, inadequately treated municipal waste-water, and poorly maintained septic systems contribute to eutrophication of drinking water sources. In agricultural areas with dense animal populations, animal waste also adds nitrogen and phosphorus to surface waters. Heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nitrates. Although these compounds are beneficial for plant life, they negatively impact humans, especially infants. EPA regulations require nitrate concentrations of less than 10 ppm, and nitrite concentration of less than 1 ppm for drinking water ().

pageData.question: Which of these can cause negative impacts in humans if the level exceeds 10 ppm in drinking water?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nitrates. Although these compounds are beneficial for plant life, they negatively impact humans, especially infants. EPA regulations require nitrate concentrations of less than 10 ppm, and nitrite concentration of less than 1 ppm for drinking water

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT a common contributor to eutrophication?

options.text: fertilizer runoff from farms and lawns

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Fertilizer runoff from lawns and farms, inadequately treated municipal wastewater, and poorly maintained septic systems contribute to eutrophication of drinking water sources.

pageData.subTitle: Copper
pageData.text: Copper found in drinking water is typically due to water-leaching copper ions from the copper pipes in households. Copper contamination is generally more of a concern in newer homes. The water has greater contact area with new pipes, as there is little to no buildup of minerals on the inside of the pipes.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A section of metal pipe with a leak. The site of the leak is corroded and discolored.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A section of metal pipe with a leak. The site of the leak is corroded and discolored.

pageData.text: Copper has the greatest impact on infants and on those with specific chronic diseases. It can cause kidney and liver damage in infants with short-term exposure, and adults with long-term exposure. If the drinking water of a home is found to have high concentrations of copper, it is recommended to only use cold water for drinking and cooking and to let the water run for at least 60 seconds before use. The EPA water standard for copper is 1.3 ppm.

pageData.subTitle: Practical Concerns
pageData.text: There are practical, non-health related concerns that the EPA has set for water quality, known as the . These standards cover aesthetic effects, which impact the appearance, smell, and taste of water; cosmetic effects such as fluoride concentrations, which can negatively affect tooth enamel; and technical effects such as pH, which can damage the water infrastructure.

Hard water is water that contains high concentrations of minerals, such as calcium and magnesium. Hard water is not typically a health hazard, but it can cause inconveniences in a household. As hard water flows through pipes, the minerals can deposit along the interior of the pipes if the water is sufficiently hard. This buildup can become so prominent that it may begin to block water flow, especially in appliances such as water heaters, which typically have very narrow passages that can be easily blocked by mineral deposits. Many contaminants also have an impact on the taste of water due to the various concentrations of minerals and cleaning agents present. Despite the taste, hard household water can still be safe to drink.

Hard water also reduces the efficacy of soaps. Magnesium and calcium ions react with soap such that they reduce the ability of soap to lather and remove dirt. Even in locations with clean drinking water, it is still possible to have hard water because EPA guidelines do not specify testing for calcium and magnesium.

pageData.subTitle: pH
pageData.text: Water contains hydrogen ions (H+) and hydroxyl ions (OH–). The concentration of H+ ions determines the pH. If the concentration of H+ ions is higher than that of OH– ions, the pH is less than 7.0 and is considered acidic. Thus, the greater the concentration of H+ ions, the lower the pH. If the concentration of H+ ions is lower than that of OH– ions, the pH is greater than 7.0 and is considered alkaline (or basic). The pH scale ranges from 0 to 14 and is logarithmic, meaning that as the pH increases by one whole number, the H+ ion concentration decreases 10 times. For example, a pH change from 5 to 6 indicates a tenfold decrease in H+ concentration, and a pH change from 4 to 6 indicates a hundredfold decrease in H+ concentration.

Water rarely exists at the neutral pH of 7. Salt water is typically slightly basic, with a pH of 8 or higher. Freshwater usually has a pH of 6.5, but this varies greatly between bodies of water. Organic materials can affect the pH of water. Fallen leaves often contain tannic acid, which stains the water brown and reduces pH. Some bacteria create acidic waste products that also lower the pH of water. Acid rain has a widespread effect on natural waterways in the United States as well. One factor leading to acid rain is the burning of fossil fuels. This process releases oxides of nitrogen and sulfur into the atmosphere, where they mix with atmospheric water to form nitric and sulfuric acids. Thus, the acids mix with rainwater and are delivered to natural waterways and soils. Normal rain has a pH of 5.6 (due to dissolved carbon dioxide from the atmosphere forming carbonic acid). Rain is considered to be “acid rain” if the pH is lower than 5.6. Drinking water that is excessively acidic leaches metals such as copper and lead from pipes, potentially leading to hazardous drinking water conditions in households.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: A pH scale showing the pHs of common household substances.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A pH scale showing the pHs of common household substances.

pageData.subTitle: Iron
pageData.text: Similar to copper, iron found in drinking water is typically due to the use of iron piping. Rust accumulates in older iron pipes and then dissolves into the drinking water. There are very few health concerns associated with iron in the water; in fact, it is not even among the primary EPA tests for drinking water. However, iron can lead to metallic tasting water and discoloration of fixtures, which is why it has a secondary water standard of 0.3 ppm.

pageData.question: If a household water source starts with a pH of 6, then has a tenfold increase in H<sup>+</sup> concentration, what is the new pH of the water?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A pH change from 6 to 5 indicates a tenfold increase in H<sup>+</sup> concentration.

pageData.question: At what value is rain considered to be “acid rain”?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Acid rain has a pH less than 5.6.

Wear your safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron anytime you are working with chemicals, including the test strips.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for these water test activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after each activity. Clean up the work space with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What percentage of water on Earth is freshwater?
Why are municipal water supplies typically disinfected with chlorine?
A poorly maintained septic system is leaking human waste into nearby sources of freshwater, resulting in rapid algae growth. Which of the following describes this phenomenon?
Which of these metals has the greatest impact on infants and on people with specific chronic diseases if ingested?
Which of the following types of drinking water can lead to metals leaching from pipes, potentially leading to hazardous drinking water conditions if found in excess in households?
Which of the following contaminants can lead to metallic tasting water and discoloration of fixtures, but has generally very few health concerns?
Which of the following is NOT true regarding hard water?

options.text: It is an extreme health hazard.
It can cause water flow to be blocked in pipes.
It can reduce the efficacy of soaps.
It contains high concentrations of minerals.
It can impact the taste of water.

assestmentData.question: If the household water source has a hundredfold decrease in H<sup>+</sup> concentration from 5.5, what is the new pH of the water source?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activity.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work space.
Using the 100 mL graduated cylinder, fill a plastic cup with 200 mL of filtered or bottled water.
Label the cup “Filtered Water” with a marker.
Using the 100 mL graduated cylinder, fill a second plastic cup with 200 mL of tap water.
Label the cup “Tap Water” with a marker.

In Activity 1, you will use the WaterWorks<sup>™</sup> test kit to compare the pH, total alkalinity, total hardness, nitrate/nitrite, iron, copper, free chlorine and total chlorine values of tap water and filtered water.
Test both water samples following the parameters listed in your WaterWorks™ kit. Record your results in Data Table 1.
You will be performing the following tests:

text: Free Chlorine and Total Chlorine Test

pageData.text: For the Free & Total Chlorine test, you do not need to use the 500 mL sample as indicated in the kit instructions; for this test, use the same 200 mL samples you are using for the other tests.
Every time a color of a sample is compared to what is on the corresponding chart in this kit, take a photograph of your sample being held up to the chart.
Be very aware of the timing involved in testing some of these parameters, as some are required to be matched with its corresponding chart in very specific time frames to get accurate results.

text: Used test strips can be disposed of in the household trash.
Water samples can be poured down the sink.
Clean and dry the cups, and return them to the equipment set.

pageData.title: Thank you
pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.text: *Although pH is not measured as a concentration, record the number indicated by the color on the test strip in the “concentration” box in Data Table 1.

data.title: Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
data.content: The US government agency that regulates policies that protect human health and the environment

data.title: Eutrophication
data.content: A natural, usually gradual process that increases sediment and nutrient availability in water bodies

data.title: Hard water
data.content: Water that contains high concentrations of minerals, such as calcium and magnesium

data.title: Secondary Drinking Water Standards
data.content: Non-enforeceable guidelines regulating contaminants that may cause cosmetic effects (such as as skin or tooth discoloration) or aesthetic effects (such as taste, odor, or color) in drinking water
